title: 110_hr3981
content:
The "Preserve America and Save America's Treasures Act" establishes the Preserve America and Save America's Treasures programs, with defined purposes, definitions, and regulations. Authorization of appropriations is also included. The Preserve America Program authorizes grants, recognition programs, and efforts by Federal agencies to support historic resource preservation. The definitions in this title include terms like "Council" referring to the Advisory Council on Historic Preservation, "heritage tourism" as activities attracting visitors based on unique historical and cultural aspects, "program" as the Preserve America Program, and "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior. The Preserve America Program, established in the Department of the Interior, allows the Secretary to provide grants for preservation efforts to States, local governments, Indian tribes, and designated communities. Eligible projects include research and documentation of community history. The Preserve America Program offers grants for preservation efforts to States, local governments, Indian tribes, and designated communities. Eligible projects include research, education, interpretation, planning for economic development, training for professional development, and support for heritage tourism in designated communities. The Secretary may provide grants for nonconstruction projects promoting historic properties or public education. Only one grant per project is allowed. Preference may be given to projects aligning with both the program and Save America's Treasures Program. The Secretary consults with the Council and notifies selected projects at least 30 days in advance. The Secretary must notify relevant committees 30 days before granting funds for eligible projects. Projects must cover at least 50% of the total cost themselves. The Secretary requires applicants to provide cash or donated supplies for the non-Federal share of eligible projects before receiving a grant under the program. SEC. 104. DESIGNATION OF PRESERVE AMERICA COMMUNITIES. To be designated as a Preserve America Community, a community, tribal area, or neighborhood must submit an application containing required information and meet criteria set by the Council, including the protection and celebration of heritage, economic development through historic assets, and promotion of education and heritage tourism programs. The Council will establish an expedited process for Preserve America Community designation for local governments previously certified for historic preservation activities. Guidelines will be established in consultation with the Secretary to carry out this section. SEC. 105. REGULATIONS.

The Secretary will develop guidelines and regulations necessary to implement this title.

SEC. 106. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

$25,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2009 to 2013 for this title.

TITLE II--SAVE AMERICA'S TREASURES PROGRAM

SEC. 201. PURPOSE. TITLE II--SAVE AMERICA'S TREASURES PROGRAM

SEC. 201. PURPOSE.

This title authorizes the Save America's Treasures Program under the Department of the Interior, to be managed by the Director of the National Park Service in collaboration with various organizations. The terms defined in this section include "collection," "eligible entity," "historic property," and "nationally significant," all related to the Save America's Treasures Program under the Department of the Interior. The Save America's Treasures Program, established under section 203(a), is overseen by the Secretary of the Interior through the National Park Service Director. The Save America's Treasures Program is established under section 203 and overseen by the Secretary of the Interior through the National Park Service Director. The Save America's Treasures program, established in the Department of the Interior, provides grants to eligible entities for projects preserving nationally significant collections and historic properties. At least 50 percent of the funds are allocated for these projects through a competitive grant process administered by the Secretary. Eligible entities must submit applications to be considered for grants. To be eligible for a competitive grant under the Save America's Treasures program, a collection or historic property must be nationally significant and threatened or endangered. The Secretary will consult with relevant organizations to determine the national significance of collections. To qualify for a competitive grant under the program, a historic property must be listed in the National Register of Historic Places at the national level of significance or designated as a National Historic Landmark. The Secretary will only provide grants to projects that eliminate or mitigate threats to the property, have a clear public benefit, and can be completed on schedule and within budget. The Secretary may give preference to projects that align with the program and Preserve America Program. Only one grant will be provided per eligible project. The Secretary must consult with relevant organizations when preparing the list of projects for grants. The Secretary will recuse entities that have applied for a grant from consultation requirements. The Secretary must notify relevant committees 30 days before providing grants for the fiscal year. Non-Federal cost-sharing is required for projects receiving grants. The non-Federal share of project costs under a grant must be at least 50%, in the form of cash or donated supplies/services. Applicants must demonstrate capacity to secure this share before receiving a grant. The Secretary will develop guidelines and regulations to implement the title. $50,000,000 is authorized annually for this purpose. No funds from this Act can be used for National Heritage Area activities.
